docs.title: Commands
docs.text: This section lists all available commands and subcommands supported by AI-services.

docs.title: Command: ai-services application
docs.text: Description: Manage application configuration.

docs.title: Command: ai-services completion
docs.text: Description: Generates the autocompletion script for specified shell.

docs.title: Command: ai-services help
docs.text: Description: Displays a list of all available commands and their brief descriptions. The help command can also be used to view detailed usage information for a specific command or subcommand.

docs.title: Command: ai-services version
docs.text: Description: Displays detailed version information.

docs.title: Frequently Asked Questions
docs.text: This is a placeholder.

docs.title: Installation Guide
docs.text: This guide walks you through installing and configuring AI-services on a RHEL environment. Before you begin, confirm that all prerequisites are satisfied.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• HMC-based access (UI and/or CLI)

  • Spyre cards are attached, discoverable, and ACTIVATED (x cards)

  • Podman is installed and running

  • Hardware - 1 LPAR (16 CPUs (NUMA aligned), 768GB RAM, 600GB Storage) // check with the team once

docs.title: Pull in the go binary
docs.text:
Download the latest ai-services binary from the releases page.

Use the following curl command to download it (replace <version> with the desired release tag):

curl -LO https://example.com/ai-services/releases/download/<version>/<ai-services-binary>
sudo mv <ai-services-binary> /usr/local/bin/
sudo chmod +x <ai-services-binary>

docs.title: Run the binary to get started
docs.text:
% ai-services
A CLI tool for managing AI services infrastructure.

Usage:
  ai-services [command]

Available Commands:
  application Deploy and monitor the applications
  completion  Generate the autocompletion script for the specified shell
  help        Help about any command
  version     Prints CLI version with more info

Flags:
  -h, --help      help for ai-services
  -v, --version   version for ai-services

Use "ai-services [command] --help" for more information about a command.

Note: The LPAR environment is configured and validated each time an application is created.

docs.title: Enable autocompletion feature (Optional) -> Shall be moved away from initial setup
docs.text: Enable shell autocompletion for the CLI. Once activated, the CLI automatically suggests commands, flags, and arguments as you type, improving speed and reducing errors.

docs.title: Enable for bash
docs.text: % source < (ai-services completion bash)

docs.title: Enable for fish
docs.text: % source < (ai-services completion fish)

docs.title: Enable for bash
docs.text: % source < (ai-services completion bash)

docs.title: Enable for powershell
docs.text: % source < (ai-services completion powershell)

docs.title: Limitations
docs.text:
The following section outlines the current constraints and known issues of the tool, based on its present design and implementation.

  • User authentication and multi-tenancy are not supported.
  • Image Processing in PDFs is not supported.
  • The tool supports only a single LPAR environment; multi-LPAR configurations are not currently supported.
  • The tool is supported only on RHEL operating systems.
  • Only PDFs ingestions and processing is supported.
  • UI and catalog features are planned for future but are not included in the current scope.

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text:
This section helps diagnose and resolve common issues encountered while using the tool.

Before reporting any issue, we recommend re-configuring the environment and validating the setup.

~ % ai-services bootstrap configure
Running bootstrap configuration...
✅ Current user is root.
✅ Podman already configured
✅ IBM Spyre Accelerator is attached to the LPAR
ServiceReport output: servicereport 2.2.5

Spyre configuration checks             PASS

 VFIO Driver configuration             PASS
 User memlock configuration            PASS
 sos config                    PASS   Auto Fixed
 sos package                    PASS
 VFIO udev rules configuration           PASS
 User group configuration             PASS   Auto Fixed
 VFIO device permission              PASS
 VFIO kernel module loaded             PASS
 VFIO module dep configuration           PASS

Memlock limit is set for the sentient group.
Spyre user must be in the sentient group.
To add run below command:
    sudo usermod -aG sentient <user>
    Example:
    sudo usermod -aG sentient abc
    Re-login as <user>.

✅ Spyre cards configuration validated successfully.
✅ Bootstrap configuration completed successfully.


~ % ai-services bootstrap validate
Running bootstrap validation...
✅ Current user is root.
✅ Operating system is RHEL  {"version": "9.6"}
✅ System is registered with RHN
✅ System is running on IBM Power11 architecture
✅ IBM Spyre Accelerator is attached to the LPAR
✅ All validations passed

docs.title: Symptom:
docs.text: Error: layer 1: failed pod creation: failed to execute podman kube play: playing YAML file: adding pod to state: name "test--vllm-server" is in use: pod already exists

docs.title: Possible Causes:
docs.text:
• Application creation failed during execution.
  • Application creation stopped unexpectedly before completion.
  • Application teardown failed or was skipped.
  • Application name is redundant.

docs.title: Resolution:
docs.text:
1. Check if any partial resources are still active.

    bash ai-services application ps

  2. If the conflicting pod shows up, manually clean up the pod and any residue from the application left behind.

    bash ai-services application delete <application_name>

docs.title: Symptom:
docs.text: Error: layer 1: failed pod creation: f...image configuration: fetching blob: denied: Your account has exceeded its pull traffic quota for the current month.

docs.title: Resolution:
docs.text: Contact project-ai-service if you hit this error. (Placeholder)

docs.title: ai-services application
docs.text:
This command enables you to create and manage applications. It includes the following subcommands:

  • create
  • delete
  • image
  • info
  • logs
  • model
  • ps
  • start
  • stop
  • templates

docs.title: Command: ai-services completion
docs.text:
Description: Generates the autocompletion script for specified shell

Subcommands:

Subcommand Description ai-services completion bash Generate the autocompletion script for bash ai-services completion fish Generate the autocompletion script for fish ai-services completion powershell Generate the autocompletion script for powershell ai-services completion zsh Generate the autocompletion script for zsh

docs.title: Command: ai-services help
docs.text:
Description: Displays a list of all available commands and their brief descriptions. The help command can also be used to view detailed usage information for a specific command or subcommand.

Usage: 

ai-services [command] help
ai-services [command] --help
ai-services help

docs.title: Command: ai-services version
docs.text:
Description: Displays detailed version information

Usage

ai-services version
ai-services [command] --version
ai-services [command] -v

% ai-services version
Version: 732d48a
GitCommit: 732d48a
BuildDate: 2025-11-04T07:33:42Z
% ai-services --version
ai-services version 732d48a
% ai-services -v
ai-services version 732d48a

docs.title: Description
docs.text: The application command allows you to deploy new applications and monitor their status. On successful execution of create command, the next steps are displayed in the terminal itself.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text: ai-services application create [name] [flags]

docs.title: Example
docs.text: ai-services application create rag-application-1 -t RAG --params UI_PORT=3000

docs.title: Flags
docs.text: Flag Description -t, --template string Template name to use (required) --params strings Values Supported: UI_PORT=8000 --skip-model-download Set to true to skip model download during application creation --skip-validation strings Skip specific validation checks (comma-separated: root,rhel,rhn,power11,rhaiis) -h, --help Show help message --verbose Enable detailed logs.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: The delete command allows you to remove an existing application deployment along with its related configurations and resources.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text: ai-services application delete [name] [flags]

docs.title: Example
docs.text: ai-services application delete rag-application-1

docs.title: Flags
docs.text: Flag Description -h, --help Show help message

docs.title: Description
docs.text: The image command allows you to pull new container images and list the images required by the application template.

docs.title: Avaiable Commands
docs.text: Command Description list List container images for a given application template pull Pulls all container images for a given application template

docs.title: Usage
docs.text: ai-services application image [command] [flags]

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
ai-services application image list --template RAG
ai-services application image list  -t RAG 
ai-services application image pull  -t RAG

docs.title: Flags
docs.text: Flag Description -t, --template string Template name to use (required) -h, --help Show help message

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Displays the information about the running application

docs.title: Usage
docs.text: ai-services application info [name] [flags]

docs.title: Example
docs.text: ai-services application info rag-application-1

docs.title: Flags
docs.text: Flag Description -h, --help Show help message

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Displays the logs from application pods and containers.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text: ai-services application logs [flags]

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
ai-services application logs --pod temp--pod3
ai-services application logs --pod temp--pod3 --container 4166daebd7a0

docs.title: Flags
docs.text: Flag Description --container string Container logs to show logs from (Optional) -h, --help Show help message --pod string Pod name to show logs from (required)

docs.title: Description
docs.text: The model command allows you to download new models and list the models required by the application template.

docs.title: Avaiable Commands
docs.text: Command Description download Download models for a given application template list List models for a given application template

docs.title: Usage
docs.text: ai-services application model [command] [flags]

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
ai-services application model list --template RAG
ai-services application model list  -t RAG 
ai-services application model download  -t RAG

docs.title: Flags
docs.text: Flag Description -t, --template string Template name to use (required) -h, --help Show help message

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Similar to podman ps - lists containers deployed by AI-services

docs.title: Usage
docs.text: ai-services application ps [name] [flags]

docs.title: Example
docs.text: ai-services application ps rag-application-1

docs.title: Flags
docs.text: Flag Description -h, --help Show help message

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Starts all or specific pods in the application

docs.title: Usage
docs.text: ai-services application start [name] [flags]

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
ai-services application start rag-application-1
ai-services application start --pod rag-application-1--pod-name

docs.title: Flags
docs.text: Flag Description --pod string Specific pod name(s) to start (optional) --skip-logs Skip displaying logs after starting the pod -h, --help Show help message

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Stops all or specific pods in the application

docs.title: Usage
docs.text: ai-services application stop [name] [flags]

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
ai-services application stop rag-application-1
ai-services application stop --pod rag-application-1--pod-name

docs.title: Flags
docs.text: Flag Description --pod string Specific pod name(s) to stop (optional) --skip-logs Skip displaying logs after starting the pod -h, --help Show help message

docs.title: Description
docs.text: List available application templates

docs.title: Usage
docs.text: ai-services application templates

docs.title: Example
docs.text: ai-services application templates

docs.title: Flags
docs.text: Flag Description -h, --help Show help message

docs.title: Installing in air-gapped environment
docs.text: This guide provides detailed instructions for installing the application in environments without external internet connectivity. It outlines the prerequisites, offline resource preparation, and deployment process.

docs.title: Environment Setup
docs.text:
Two machines are required to perform the installation in an air-gapped environment:

  • Bastion(Jump) LPAR

    • A system with active internet connectivity used to download all required installation artifacts, container images, and dependencies.

    • Save and package all necessary files for offline use.

    • Transfer the downloaded resources to the air-gapped environment through internal network share.

  • AI Services LPAR

    • The target deployment environment with no internet access.

    • Use local or internal repositories to perform the installation.

Note: The machines should be network-accessible to each other.

For the purpose of this tutorial, example IP addresses are used to illustrate the setup. Replace these values with the actual IPs from your environment when performing the installation.

  • Bastion LPAR:

    • Private Network: 192.168.0.94

    • Public Network: 10.20.187.80

  • AI Services LPAR:

    • Private n/w: 192.168.0.39

Fig 1.0 - Air-gapped environment

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text: These steps must be executed on the bastion host (until mentioned otherwise), which acts as the intermediary system for fetching and preparing resources for the air-gapped environment.

docs.title: Proxy Configuration (Optional)
docs.text:
If the target workload operates in a semi-air-gapped environment or requires controlled outbound access (for example, through a Secure Proxy Access Relay – SPAR), configure a Squid proxy on the connected machine.

  1. Install Squid

    $ yum install squid

  2. Start the Squid Service

    $ systemctl start squid

  3. Enable Squid on System Boot

    $ systemctl enable squid

  4. Verify Status

    $ systemctl status squid

Once the Squid service is running, it will listen on port 3128 by default.

docs.title: Install Podman
docs.text:
1. Install Podman

    $ dnf install -y podman

  2. Verify the installation

    $ podman --version

docs.title: Pull AI-services binary
docs.text:
Use the following curl command to download it (replace <version> with the desired release tag):

$ curl -LO https://example.com/ai-services/releases/download/<version>/<ai-services-binary>
$ sudo mv <ai-services-binary> /usr/local/bin/
$ sudo chmod +x <ai-services-binary>

After the bastion host is prepared with the necessary prerequisites, begin downloading the assets needed for the target environment.

docs.title: Download images and models
docs.text:
1. Pull the listed images

    $ ai-services application image pull --template <template_name>

  2. List the models used

    $ ai-services application model list --template <template_name>

  3. Download the models

    $ ai-services application model download --template <template_name>

docs.title: Package the Downloaded Assets
docs.text:
Once all required assets have been downloaded on the bastion host, package them into compressed archives. These archives will be used for transferring the assets to the target air-gapped environment.

  1. Create TAR archive for images. Create a separate compressed archive for every image.

    $ podman save -o <image_1>.tar <image_name>:<image_tag>

  2. Create TAR archive for models

    $ tar -I pigz -cvf models.tar.gz /var/lib/ai-services/models

docs.title: Transfer assets to target machines (AI Services LPAR)
docs.text:
Transfer the assets from the bastion host to the target air-gapped environment using secure media.(Replace the IP address, these are examples)

$ scp *.tar root@192.168.0.94:/root
$ scp models.tar.gz root@192.168.0.94:/root
$ scp <ai-services-binary> root@192.168.0.94:/root

docs.title: Deploying in air-gapped environment
docs.text: The following steps should be run on the air-gapped environment i.e the target environment.

docs.title: 1. Register to RHN (Optional)
docs.text:
We register the target to Red Hat Network (RHN) through the Squid proxy created on the bastion. This is one supported approach; other registration methods may exist and are out of scope for this document.

Open /etc/rhsm/rhsm.conf file and edit following settings:

#an http proxy server to use
proxy_hostname = 192.168.0.39

#port for http proxy server
proxy_port = 3128

docs.title: 2. Setup AI services binary
docs.text:
$ sudo chmod +x <ai-services-binary>
$ sudo mv <ai-services-binary> /usr/local/bin/

docs.title: 3. Load container images and models
docs.text:
Import the pre-packaged container images and associated model artifacts into the air-gapped environment to make them available for deployment.

$ for file in *.tar; do podman load -i "$file"; done
$ tar -I pigz -xvf models.tar.gz -C /

docs.title: 4. Create the application
docs.text:
Create the application with flag --skip-model-download

ai-services application create test1 --template rag-air --skip-model-download

docs.title: Tutorial
docs.text:
// TO-DO - make the tutorial use case specific

This tutorial guides you through listing available templates, creating an application from a template, monitoring its status, and cleaning up when you're done. It assumes your environment is already configured and validated.

Tip: If you have not yet set up your environment, complete the steps in Installation first.

docs.title: List all available templates
docs.text: ai-services application templates

docs.title: Create an application
docs.text:
Choose a template and a unique name for your application.

ai-services application create <app_name> --template-name=<template_name>

Deployment can take a few minutes. You can relax while the resources are provisioned.

the successful deployment should have some sort of message displayed

Once deployment completes, you can monitor pod status and readiness with the ai-services application ps command.

docs.title: Cleanup
docs.text:
When you're finished, delete the application to free resources.

ai-services application stop <app_name>
ai-services application delete <app_name>
